{{Short description|School of Christian theology}} {{Feminism sidebar|Variants (religious)}} {{Christianity|expanded=hide}}
'''Christian feminism''' is a school of [[Christian theology]] which seeks to advance and understand the [[sexual equality|equality]] of [[men]] and [[women]] morally, socially, spiritually, and in leadership from a [[Christianity|Christian]] perspective.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hassey|first=Janette|date=1989|title= A Brief History of Christian Feminism|jstor=43052265|journal=Transformation|volume=6|issue=2|pages=1–5|doi=10.1177/026537888900600201|s2cid=150983833 }}</ref> Christian [[feminist]]s argue that contributions by women, and an acknowledgment of women's value, are necessary for a complete understanding of [[Christianity]].<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/0966735007072020|title = Modern Women, Traditional Abrahamic Religions and Interpreting Sacred Texts|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 15|issue = 2|pages = 145–159|year = 2007|last1 = Harrison|first1 = Victoria S.| s2cid=145641264 }}</ref> Christian feminists believe that [[God in Christianity|God]] does not [[Sexism|discriminate]] on the basis of biologically-determined characteristics such as sex and race, but created all humans to exist in harmony and equality, regardless of race or [[gender]].<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1080/08164649993083|title = Theme: Feminisms, Religions, Cultures, Identities|journal = Australian Feminist Studies|volume = 14|issue = 30|pages = 255–258|year = 1999|last1 = McPhillips|first1 = Kathleen}}</ref> Christian feminists generally advocate for anti-[[essentialism]] as a part of their belief system, acknowledging that gender identities do not mandate a certain set of personality traits.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McLeod-Harrison|first=Mark S.|date=September 2014|title=Christian Feminism, Gender and Human Essences: Toward a Solution of the Sameness and Differences Dilemma|journal=Forum Philosophicum|volume=19 |issue=2|pages=169–191|doi=10.5840/forphil20141921}}</ref> Their major issues include the [[ordination of women]], [[Christian egalitarianism|biblical equality]] in [[marriage]], recognition of equal spiritual and moral abilities, [[abortion rights]], integration of [[Gender-neutral pronouns|gender neutral pronouns]] within readings of the Bible, and the search for a feminine or gender-transcendent divine.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500100002604|title = 'Working for Change in the Position of Women in the Church': Christian Women's Information and Resources (CWIRES) and the British Christian Women's Movement, 1972-1990|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 9|issue = 26|pages = 44–69|year = 2001|last1 = Daggers|first1 = Jenny| s2cid=144674091 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673509900002206|title = The Future of Christian Feminist Theologies—As I Sense it: Musings on the Effects of Historiography and Space|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 8|issue = 22|pages = 79–92|year = 1999|last1 = McEwan|first1 = Dorothea| s2cid=144816076 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/0966735007072034|title = The Possibility of a Gender-Transcendent God: Taking Macmurray Forward|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 15|issue = 2|pages = 236–255|year = 2007|last1 = McLntosh|first1 = Esther| s2cid=145121811 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500401300104|title = In Woman's Image: An Iconography for God|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 13|pages = 40–61|year = 2004|last1 = Polinska|first1 = Wioleta| s2cid=170205207 }}</ref> Christian feminists often draw on the teachings of other religions and ideologies in addition to biblical evidence, and other Christian based texts throughout history that advocate for women's rights.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673509900002103|title = Thealogy and Theology: Mutually Exclusive or Creatively Interdependent?|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 7|issue = 21|pages = 21–38|year = 1999|last1 = Clack|first1 = Beverley| s2cid=143523339 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hassey|first=Janette|date=April 1989|title=A Brief History of Christian Feminism|journal= Transformation: An International Journal of Holistic Mission Studies|volume=6|issue=2|pages=1–5|doi=10.1177/026537888900600201|s2cid=150983833 }}</ref>
The term ''[[Christian egalitarianism]]'' is often preferred by those advocating gender equality and equity among Christians who do not wish to associate themselves with the [[Feminist movements and ideologies|feminist movement]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Groothuis |first=Rebecca M. |url=http://www.christianethicstoday.com/CET/CET/CETJournal.pdf |title=Feminism Goes to Seed |journal=Christian Ethics Today |volume=5 |issue=6 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304195222/http://www.christianethicstoday.com/CET/CET/CETJournal.pdf |archive-date=2016-03-04 }}</ref>
== History ==
Some Christian feminists believe that the principle of egalitarianism was present in the teachings of [[Jesus]] and the early Christian movements such as [[Marianismo]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Universidade Federal da Bahia: Mariana Cardoso Carvalho {{!}} Gênero {{!}} Etnia, raça e gênero|url=https://pt.scribd.com/document/400489853/9-As-Primeiras-Fronteiras-Fernando-Fernandez-e-Bernardo-Araujo|work=Scribd|access-date=2020-01-10|language=pt|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227164456/https://pt.scribd.com/document/400489853/9-As-Primeiras-Fronteiras-Fernando-Fernandez-e-Bernardo-Araujo|archive-date=2020-02-27|url-status=dead}}</ref> but this is a highly contested view by many feminist scholars who believe that Christianity itself relies heavily on [[gender role]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Sally K.|date=2004|title=The Marginalization of Evangelical Feminism|journal=Sociology of Religion|volume=65|issue=3|pages=215–237|doi=10.2307/3712250|issn=1069-4404|jstor=3712250}}</ref> {{by whom|date=August 2018}} These interpretations of Christian origins have been criticized by secular feminists for "anachronistically projecting contemporary ideals back into the first century."<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 20487897|title = Christian Origins, Egalitarianism, and Utopia|journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion|volume = 23|issue = 2|pages = 27–49|last1 = Beavis|first1 = Mary Ann|year = 2007|doi = 10.2979/FSR.2007.23.2.27| s2cid=144025040 }}</ref> In the [[Middle Ages]] [[Julian of Norwich]] and [[Hildegard of Bingen]] explored the idea of a divine power with both masculine and feminine characteristics.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bauerschmidt |first=Frederick Christian |title=Seeing Jesus: Julian of Norwich and the Text of Christ's Body |journal=Journal of Medieval and Early Modern Studies |volume=27 |issue=2 |year=1997 |pages=189–214}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/096673509900002203| title=Hildegard of Bingen: A Woman for our Time| journal=Feminist Theology| volume=8| issue=22| pages=25–41| year=1999| last1=Boyce-Tillman| first1=June| s2cid=144317390}}</ref> Feminist works from the fifteenth to seventeenth centuries addressed objections to women learning, teaching and preaching in a religious context.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673509900002206|title = The Future of Christian Feminist Theologies—As I Sense it: Musings on the Effects of Historiography and Space|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 8|issue = 22|pages = 79–92|year = 1999|last1 = McEwan|first1 = Dorothea| s2cid=144816076 }}</ref> One such proto-feminist was [[Anne Hutchinson]] who was cast out of the [[Puritan]] colony of [[Massachusetts]] for teaching on the dignity and rights of women.<ref>Ellsberg, Robert. ''All Saints: Daily Reflections on Saints, Prophets, and Witnesses from Our Time''</ref><ref>{{cite book|isbn=978-0824516796|title=All Saints: Daily Reflections on Saints, Prophets, and Witnesses for Our Time|last1=Ellsberg|first1=Robert|year=1997|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/allsaintsdailyre00ells}}</ref>
The [[First-wave feminism|first wave]] of feminism in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries included an increased interest in the place of women in religion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hassey|first=Janette|date=April 1989|title=A Brief History of Christian Feminism|journal= Transformation: An International Journal of Holistic Mission Studies|volume=6|issue=2|pages=1–5|doi=10.1177/026537888900600201|s2cid=150983833 }}</ref> Women who were campaigning for their rights began to question their inferiority both within the church and in other spheres, which had previously been justified by church teachings.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/096673500301200107| title=Imagining God in Our Ways: The Journals of Frances E. Willard| journal=Feminist Theology| volume=12| pages=75–88| year=2003| last1=Capitani| first1=Diane| s2cid=144031930}}</ref> Some Christian feminists of this period were [[Marie Maugeret]], [[Katharine Bushnell]], [[Catherine Booth]], [[Frances Willard (suffragist)|Frances Willard]], and [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]].
During the 1960s and the 1970s many evangelical women were influenced by the [[civil rights movement]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Sally K.|date=2004|title=The Marginalization of Evangelical Feminism|journal=Sociology of Religion|volume=65|issue=3|pages=215–237|doi=10.2307/3712250|issn=1069-4404|jstor=3712250}}</ref> Christian Feminists began writing and publishing articles that addressed reproductive rights as well as inequality in marriage and in the religious hierarchy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Sally K.|date=2004|title=The Marginalization of Evangelical Feminism|journal=Sociology of Religion|volume=65|issue=3|pages=215–237|doi=10.2307/3712250|issn=1069-4404|jstor=3712250}}</ref> In response to these articles, groups such as the EWC or [[Evangelical Women's Caucus]], and the ESA or [[Evangelicals for Societal Action]] were formed in order to create a social movement in the church towards equality, which was motivated by the Christian Feminist ideal that God created all people as equals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Sally K.|date=2004|title=The Marginalization of Evangelical Feminism|journal=Sociology of Religion|volume=65|issue=3|pages=215–237|doi=10.2307/3712250|issn=1069-4404|jstor=3712250}}</ref>
== Issues == {{Christianity and gender|positions}}
=== Women in church leadership === {{main|Ordination of women}}
The division of [[Protestantism|Protestant]] belief systems into different denominations allowed for women to acquire far more leadership positions in the church, as certain denominations then had the freedom to advocate for female leadership.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hassey|first=Janette|date=April 1989|title=A Brief History of Christian Feminism|journal=Transformation: An International Journal of Holistic Mission Studies|volume=6|issue=2|pages=1–5|doi=10.1177/026537888900600201|s2cid=150983833 |issn=0265-3788}}</ref> In both mainline and liberal branches of [[Protestantism|Protestant Christianity]], women are ordained as [[clergy]]. Even some theologically conservative denominations, such as [[The Church of the Nazarene]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Church of the Nazarene Manual |date=2017 |publisher=Nazarene Publishing House |location=Kansas City, MO |isbn=978-0-8341-3711-0 |page=192 |url=http://www.nazarene.org/sites/default/files/docs/GenSec/Manual/2017%20-2021%20Manual |access-date=20 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831220223/http://www.nazarene.org/sites/default/files/docs/GenSec/Manual/2017%20-2021%20Manual |archive-date=31 August 2018 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and [[Assemblies of God]],<ref>{{cite web |date=1990-08-14 |url=http://ag.org/top/beliefs/position_papers/pp_downloads/pp_4191_women_ministry.pdf |title=The Role of Women in Ministry |pages=7 |publisher=The General Council of the Assemblies of God |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20060523225854/http://ag.org/top/beliefs/position_papers/pp_downloads/pp_4191_women_ministry.pdf |archive-date=2006-05-23 |url-status=dead }}</ref> ordain women as pastors. However, the [[Roman Catholic Church]], the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], the [[Southern Baptist Convention]] (the largest Protestant denomination in the U.S.),<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sbc.net/aboutus/pswomen.asp |title=SBC Position Statements - Women in Ministry |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921171219/http://www.sbc.net/aboutus/pswomen.asp |archive-date=2008-09-21 |url-status=dead }}</ref> as well as [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), and many churches in the American [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] movement prohibit women from entering clerical positions.<ref>[https://doi.org/10.1007%2FBF02393417 SpringerLink - Journal Article ]</ref> Some Christian feminists believe that as women have greater opportunity to receive theological training, they will have greater influence on how scriptures are interpreted by those that deny women the right to become ministers.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/0966735007072020|title = Modern Women, Traditional Abrahamic Religions and Interpreting Sacred Texts|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 15|issue = 2|pages = 145–159|year = 2007|last1 = Harrison|first1 = Victoria S.| s2cid=145641264 }}</ref>
=== Interpretations of gender based scriptures === {{Disputed section|date=October 2018}} {{Religious text primary|section|date=March 2016}} Many of the Christian ideals concerning gender stem from interpretations of the Bible.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Kobes Du Mez|first=Kristin|date=2015|title=A New Gospel for Women: Katherine Bushnell and the Challenge of Christian Feminism|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=27–28|isbn=978-0190205645}}</ref> Christian feminists have often argued that the Bible is problematic, not because of the text itself, but because of the Christian scholars who have interpreted the scripture throughout time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mohrmann|first=Margaret|date=2015-04-24|title=Feminist Ethics and Religious Ethics|journal=Journal of Religious Ethics|volume=43|issue=2|pages=185–192|doi=10.1111/jore.12093|issn=0384-9694}}</ref> An example of these inconsistencies can be found in the [[Creation story in Genesis|creation story]] of Adam and Eve; some Evangelicals believe that Adam and Eve were created at the same time, while others believe that Eve was made from the rib of Adam.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=La Croix|first=Richard R.|date=January 1984|title=The paradox of Eden|journal=International Journal for Philosophy of Religion|volume=15|issue=3|pages=171|doi=10.1007/bf00137064|s2cid=171018210 |issn=0020-7047}}</ref> There is also wide debate within many Christian denominations over the fault of Eve concerning the consumption of the [[forbidden fruit]], and the entrance of sin into the world.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=La Croix|first=Richard R.|date=January 1984|title=The paradox of Eden|journal=International Journal for Philosophy of Religion|volume=15|issue=3|pages=171|doi=10.1007/bf00137064|s2cid=171018210 |issn=0020-7047}}</ref> Historically, a great deal of blame has been placed on Eve, but many Christian Feminists have worked to reframe the story, and shift the blame equally between both parties, as both partook of the fruit.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harvey|first=Richard|date=1991|title=Early English Feminism and the Creation Myth|journal=The Historian|volume=54|issue=1|pages=35–48|jstor=24447931|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6563.1991.tb00839.x}}</ref> The story of Adam and Eve is just one example of a text which Christian feminists believe is [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] in nature due to its interpretation.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=September 1993|title=Redeeming Eve|journal=English Literary Renaissance|volume=23|issue=3|pages=490–508|doi=10.1111/j.1475-6757.1993.tb01071.x|issn=0013-8312|last1= McChrystal|first1= Deirdre Keenan|s2cid=222443144 }}</ref> Some Christian Feminists made the decision to abandon direct scriptural use in their fight for equality, while others relied on verses that opposed patriarchal ideals, pointing out the inconsistencies within the Bible.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mohrmann|first=Margaret|date=2015-04-24|title=Feminist Ethics and Religious Ethics|journal=Journal of Religious Ethics|volume=43|issue=2|pages=185–192|doi=10.1111/jore.12093|issn=0384-9694}}</ref> The following passages act as examples of these inconsistencies.
* {{Bibleref2|Galatians|3:28}}. "There is neither…male nor female for all are one in Christ Jesus." * [[Deborah]] of the [[Old Testament]] was a [[prophetess]] and "judge of Israel"<ref>[http://www.amit.org.il/learning/english/JW/Deborah.htm Deborah the Prophetess] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219100012/http://www.amit.org.il/learning/english/JW/Deborah.htm |date=2007-12-19 }}</ref> * {{Bibleref2|Genesis|2:20}}. The word translated "help" or "helper" is the same Hebrew word, "ēzer," which the Old Testament uses more than 17 times to describe the kind of help that God brings to His people in times of need; e.g., "Thou art my help (ēzer) and my deliverer," and "My help ''(ēzer)'' comes from the Lord." Never once in all these references is the word used to indicate subordination or servitude to another human being.<ref>[http://www.godswordtowomen.org/ezerkenegdo.htm "Ezer Kenegdo" Word Study. God's Word to Women, 2011]</ref> * {{Bibleref2|Genesis|3:16}}. "To the woman he (God) said, 'I will greatly increase your pains in childbearing; in pain you shall bring forth children, yet your desire shall be for your husband, and he shall rule over you.{{' "}} * {{Bibleref2|1 Timothy|2:12}}. "But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence." * {{Bibleref2|1 Corinthians|11:7-9}}. "For a man ought not to cover his head, since he is the image and glory of God, but woman is the glory of man. For man was not made from woman, but woman from man. Neither was man created for woman, but woman for man." * {{Bibleref2|1 Corinthians|14:34}}. "The women should keep silent in the churches. For they are not permitted to speak, but should be in submission, as the Law also says." * {{Bibleref2|Colossians|3:18}}. "Wives, submit to your husbands, as is fitting in the Lord." * {{Bibleref2|1 Peter|3:1}}. "Likewise, wives, be subject to your own husbands, so that even if some do not obey the word, they may be won without a word by the conduct of their wives." * {{Bibleref2|Ephesians 5:22-24}}. "Wives, be subject to your husbands as you are to the Lord. For the husband is the head of the wife just as Christ is the head of the church, the body of which he is the Savior. Just as the church is subject to Christ, so also wives ought to be, in everything, to their husbands."
=== Reproduction, sexuality and religion === {{See also|Christianity and abortion}}
Conservative religious groups are often at philosophical odds with many feminist and liberal religious groups over [[abortion]] and the use of [[birth control]]. Scholars like sociologist Flann Campbell have argued that conservative religious denominations tend to restrict [[male]] and [[female]] sexuality<ref>{{cite journal |title = Birth Control and the Christian Churches |last = Campbell |first = Flann |journal = [[Population Studies]] |issn = 0032-4728 |volume = 14 |issue = 2 |year = 1960 |pages = 131–47 |doi = 10.2307/2172010 |jstor = 2172010 }}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yUWz24sVu54C&pg=PP13 Ordaining Women: Culture and Conflict in Religious Organizations]</ref> by prohibiting or limiting birth control use,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.vatican.va/holy_father/paul_vi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-vi_enc_25071968_humanae-vitae_en.html |title=Paul VI - Humanae Vitae<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811095540/https://www.vatican.va/holy_father/paul_vi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-vi_enc_25071968_humanae-vitae_en.html |archive-date=2007-08-11 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and condemning abortion as [[sin]]ful [[murder]].<ref>[http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/baptist/sbcabres.html Southern Baptist Convention Resolutions on Abortion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.bible-knowledge.com/Sin-of-Abortion.html Sin of Abortion and the Reasons Why<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070806191124/http://www.bible-knowledge.com/Sin-of-Abortion.html|date=2007-08-06}}</ref> Some Christian feminists (like [[Teresa Forcades]]) contend that a woman's "right to control her [[pregnancy]] is bounded by considerations of her own well-being" and that restricted access to birth control and abortion disrespect her God-given [[choice|free will]].<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500100002807|title = Revisioning Christ|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 28|pages = 82–92|year = 2001|last1 = Kim|first1 = Grace Ji-Sun| s2cid=220706278 }}</ref>
A number of socially [[Christian left|progressive]] mainline Protestant denominations as well as certain [[Jew]]ish organizations and the group [[Catholics for Choice|Catholics for a Free Choice]] have formed the [[Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice]].<ref>[http://www.rcrc.org/about/members.cfm RCRC—Member Organizations<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316134019/http://www.rcrc.org/about/members.cfm|date=2007-03-16}}</ref> The RCRC often works as a liberal feminist organization and in conjunction with other American feminist groups to oppose conservative religious denominations which, from their perspective, seek to suppress the natural reproductive rights of women.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nwlc.org/details.cfm?id=1223&section=Reproductive%20Rights%3A%20General%20Materials |title=National Women's Law Center<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715033831/https://www.nwlc.org/details.cfm?id=1223&section=Reproductive%20Rights%3A%20General%20Materials |archive-date=2007-07-15 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
In general, many Christian Feminist scholars hope to work towards a society in which female sexuality is not, in their opinion, condemned by the church, but acknowledged as a natural part of the human existence.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nove|first=Alec|chapter=Friedman, Markets and Planning: A Comment|date=1990|pages=153–163|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=9781349109937|doi=10.1007/978-1-349-10991-3_12|title=Studies in Economics and Russia}}</ref> During the Reformation, recognized [[Theology|theologians]] such as [[Martin Luther]] and [[John Calvin]] stressed the importance of [[chastity]] and marriage, leading to further repression of female sexuality within the Christian tradition.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Introducing Redemption in Christian Feminism|last=Radford Ruether|first=Rosemary|publisher=Sheffield Academic Press|year=1998|isbn=978-1-85075-888-4|location=Sheffield, England|pages=13–14}}</ref> Many Christian Feminists have stated that men in powerful religious positions have often used the scriptures, and teachings from theologians such as Calvin and Luther to both dominate and repress women sexually, a problem which Christian Feminists believe needs to be solved immediately.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nove|first=Alec|chapter=Friedman, Markets and Planning: A Comment|date=1990|pages=153–163|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=9781349109937|doi=10.1007/978-1-349-10991-3_12|title=Studies in Economics and Russia}}</ref> [[File:The birth of Christ; female angels swoon through the air; Jo Wellcome V0034607.jpg|thumb|Female Centered Depiction of the Birth of Christ]]
=== Feminine or gender-transcendent God ===
{{see also|Gender of God}}
Some Christian feminists believe that gender equality within the church cannot be achieved without rethinking the portrayal and understanding of [[God]] as a [[masculinity|masculine]] being.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500100002807|title = Revisioning Christ|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 28|pages = 82–92|year = 2001|last1 = Kim|first1 = Grace Ji-Sun| s2cid=220706278 }}</ref> The theological concept of [[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]], usually seen as replacing or synonymous with the [[Holy Spirit]] in the [[Trinity]], is often used to fulfill this desire for symbols which reflect women's religious experiences.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ignatian Spirituality and Christian Feminism|last=McCoy|first=Maria|year=2015|pages=99–100}}</ref> How Sophia is configured is not static, but usually filled with emotions and individual expression.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673509900002206|title = The Future of Christian Feminist Theologies—As I Sense it: Musings on the Effects of Historiography and Space|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 8|issue = 22|pages = 79–92|year = 1999|last1 = McEwan|first1 = Dorothea| s2cid=144816076 }}</ref> For some Christian feminists, the Sophia concept is found in a search for women who reflect contemporary feminist ideals in both the Old and New Testament. Some figures used for this purpose include the [[Virgin Mary]], [[Mary Magdalene]],<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500200002903|title = Go Tell! Thinking About Mary Magdalene|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 29|pages = 19–31|year = 2002|last1 = Winkett|first1 = Lucy| s2cid=170272653 }}</ref> [[Eve]],<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/0966735006068860|title = Book Review: The British Christian Women's Movement: A Rehabilitation of Eve|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 15|pages = 128–129|year = 2006|last1 = Isherwood|first1 = isa| s2cid=144892324 }}</ref> and [[Esther]].<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 20487926|title = Reclaiming the Hebrew Bible for Women: The Neoliberal Turn in Contemporary Feminist Scholarship|journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion|volume = 24|issue = 2|pages = 45–65|last1 = Fuchs|first1 = Esther|year = 2008|doi = 10.2979/FSR.2008.24.2.45| s2cid=145277557 }}</ref> Others see God as entirely gender-transcendent,<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/0966735007072034| title=The Possibility of a Gender-Transcendent God: Taking Macmurray Forward| journal=Feminist Theology| volume=15| issue=2| pages=236–255| year=2007| last1=McLntosh| first1=Esther| s2cid=145121811}}</ref> or focus on the feminine aspects of God and [[Jesus]].<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500100002807|title = Revisioning Christ|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 28|pages = 82–92|year = 2001|last1 = Kim|first1 = Grace Ji-Sun| s2cid=220706278 }}</ref> A female depiction of the Christ figure, known as Christa, recently arose in an attempt to allow for the power of the Christ figure to be applied to both the masculine and the feminine.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nove|first=Alec|chapter=Friedman, Markets and Planning: A Comment|date=1990|pages=153–163|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=9781349109937|doi=10.1007/978-1-349-10991-3_12|title=Studies in Economics and Russia}}</ref> Some Christian feminists use and promote gender-neutral or feminine language and imagery to describe God or Christ. Christian Feminists also call for a gender neutral reading of the Bible, as male pronouns are heavily used as compared to female pronouns throughout the text.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kurian|first=George Thomas|chapter=Women and Theology|date=2011-11-25|publisher=Blackwell Publishing Ltd|isbn=9781405157629|doi=10.1002/9780470670606.wbecc1601|title=The Encyclopedia of Christian Civilization}}</ref> The [[United Church of Christ]] describes its [[New Century Hymnal]], published in 1995, as "the only hymnal released by a Christian church that honors in equal measure both male and female images of God."<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.ucc.org/about-us/old-firsts.html | title=UCC 'Firsts' | access-date=2012-12-07 | archive-date=2017-11-15 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115110128/http://www.ucc.org/about-us/old-firsts.html | url-status=dead }}</ref>
== Feminist Theology == There are a number of academic journals dedicated to promoting feminist theological scholarship. These include:
* Journal of Feminist Studies of Religion<ref>{{Cite web|title=Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion on JSTOR|url=https://www.jstor.org/journal/jfemistudreli|access-date=2021-09-16|website=www.jstor.org|language=en}}</ref> * Women-Church Journal (1988-2007), co-editors: [[Elaine Lindsay]] and Erin White * in God's image, produced by the Asian Women's Resource Centre for Culture and Theology<ref>{{Cite web|title=in God's image – AWRC|url=https://awrc4ct.org/publications/in-gods-image/|access-date=2021-09-16|website=awrc4ct.org}}</ref> * Feminist Theology<ref>{{Cite web|title=Feminist Theology - All Issues|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/loi/fth|access-date=2021-09-16|website=SAGE Journals|language=en}}</ref>
== Critiques of Christian Feminism ==
=== Roman Catholicism === There have been multiple Popes, like Pope [[John Paul II]] and [[Pope Francis]], who have referenced a type of Feminism in their addresses to the public. Pope Francis is quoted saying the “irreplaceable role of the woman in the family … [t]he gifts of -delicacy … which are a richness of the feminine spirit, represent a genuine force for the life of the family … without which the human vocation would be unrealizable."<ref>{{Cite web|title=IN HIS THOUGHTS AND IN HIS WORDS: FRANCIS ON WOMEN by MIRIAM DUIGNAN|url=http://womensordinationcampaign.org/articles/2016/2/4/in-his-thoughts-and-in-his-words-francis-on-women-by-miriam-duignan|access-date=2020-10-11|website=Women's Ordination Worldwide|language=en-US}}</ref> Some men and women took Pope Francis words as a "vivid hope" that woman will take a more prominent role in the Catholic Church.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2014-01-25|title=Pope wants 'capillary and incisive' role for women in church|url=https://www.ncronline.org/blogs/francis-chronicles/pope-wants-capillary-and-incisive-role-women-church|access-date=2020-10-11|website=National Catholic Reporter|language=en}}</ref> These same women and men also believe that "Radical Feminism" is the cause for the teachings of then Pope John Paul II to be viewed as negative, they also believe that Pope John Paul II was taking great strides, at least for his time, to include women in the church.<ref>{{Cite web|title=A Pro-Woman Pope|url=https://www.catholiceducation.org/en/controversy/feminism/a-pro-woman-pope.html|access-date=2020-10-11|website=www.catholiceducation.org|language=en-gb}}</ref> These critics of modern-day feminism believe that the negativity is not pointed in the right direction for the women's place in the Roman Catholic church. <!-- ===Women submitting to husbands=== The following passages relate to whether wives must submit to their husbands:
* {{Bibleref2|Ephesians|5:22}} Women are told to submit to their husbands.
=== Head coverings ===
In {{Bibleref|1Corinthians|11:3–17}}, women are commanded to cover their heads in worship to show they recognize their husband's authority coming from the fact that man was created first and that he was created in God's image. However, one interpretation of this passage points out that Paul goes on to note that this was not necessary and that it was merely a cultural phenomenon, and whether women covered their heads or not was unimportant and not explicitly required.{{Fact|date=October 2008}}
== The Bible == {{Original research|date=April 2008}}
A major fundamental of Christian Feminism is how people interpret the [[Bible]], particularly the influence of one's set of presuppositions on understanding the Bible. The same passages that one [[Christian denomination|denomination]] takes to say that women may do all sorts of very important things, but not preach to adult men, a Christian feminist might interpret otherwise. An historical approach can influence a Christian feminist's understanding of a passage by taking into account the specific [[cultural]] setting and circumstance of the time that the passage was written.
In 1991 a group of leading evangelicals published the book Recovering Biblical Manhood and Womanhood: A Response to Evangelical Feminism. Various authors contributed to the book in which they present biblical arguments critiquing evangelical Feminism and supporting a "complementarian" view of manhood and womanhood.
=== Some problematic passages ===
A variety of biblical passages are used as authority to encourage women to not want leadership roles, exclusively in marriage and the pastorate.
* {{Bibleref|Job|2:10}} Job rebukes his wife for speaking as a foolish woman. The Bible also mentions men being foolish in many places. * {{Bibleref|Ecclesiastes|7:27-28}}{{Clarifyme|date=October 2008}} * {{Bibleref|Acts|1:21}} In English, being male appears as a prerequisite for apostlehood but in Greek{{Fact|date=June 2008}} the word encompasses both genders. * {{Bibleref|1Corinthians|11:3–16}} In some interpretations, women are commanded to cover their heads in worship to show they recognize their husband's authority coming from the fact that man was created first. * {{Bibleref|1Corinthians|14:34–35}} Women are told to be quiet in church. * {{Bibleref|Ephesians|5:22}} Women are told to submit to their husbands. * {{Bibleref|1Timothy|2:11–12}} Women are told to be quiet in church because man was created first, and woman was deceived and sinned first. * {{Bibleref|Revelation|2:20}} The church of Thyatira is rebuked for letting a women teach. But this is not to be considered as against women. The problem here is the teacher is leading people to sexual sins.{{Fact|date=October 2008}}

The 'virtuous woman' is described as a manager of financial affairs. * {{Bibleref|Isaiah|8:3}} An anonymous prophetess is mentioned. * {{Bibleref|Joel|2:28–29}} A prophetic forecast that women and men alike will prophesy. * {{Bibleref|Luke|2:34–38}} Anna the prophetess is present for the [[male genital mutilation|circumcision]] of baby Jesus. * Acts 9:36 A woman, Tabitha (Dorcas in Greek) is called a disciple "full of good works and almsdeeds". * {{Bibleref|Romans|16:1}} A woman, [[Phoebe]], is called a "diakonos," a Greek word meaning "one who serves", from which the English word "deacon" came. * {{Bibleref|Galatians|3:28}} "There is neither…male nor female for all are one in Christ Jesus." -->
